texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I was doing some testing with apachebench and received some peculiar results:
texts.text: I was doing some testing with apachebench and received some peculiar results:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[608487.317284] nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet
[608487.708916] nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet
[608488.010236] nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet
texts.text:
[608487.317284] nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet
[608487.708916] nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet
[608488.010236] nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've  seen this problem before  and I tried to fix it by adjusting /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip conntrack max as I did back in 2008. However, Fedora 20 doesn't have the same structure in /proc under kernel 3.12.
texts.text: I've  seen this problem before  and I tried to fix it by adjusting /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip conntrack max as I did back in 2008. However, Fedora 20 doesn't have the same structure in /proc under kernel 3.12.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The fix is to adjust /proc/sys/net/netfilter/nf conntrack max instead:
texts.text: The fix is to adjust /proc/sys/net/netfilter/nf conntrack max instead:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After a quick test, apachebench was back to normal. You can make the change permanent and test it with:
texts.text: After a quick test, apachebench was back to normal. You can make the change permanent and test it with:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are some handy connection tracking tools available in the conntrack-tools package. Take a look at the man page for conntrack and you'll find ways to review and flush the connection tracking table.
texts.text: There are some handy connection tracking tools available in the conntrack-tools package. Take a look at the man page for conntrack and you'll find ways to review and flush the connection tracking table.
